column14: Flight lesson, Flight crew member, General aviation pilot, Simulated spaceflight, Long-duration spaceflight simulation, Living in close quarters, Working in remote or confined environments, Working with human-spaceflight hardware, Zero-g aircraft, Astronaut
column15: some private pilot experience, mission specialist astronaut, experience in antarctica
column28: we did occasionally cross paths but it was not an issue
column41: I would much prefer a window in my sleep station if at all possible. also, i did not feel like there were enough places to stow my "stuff".
column54: some of the locations are clearly blocked by a crew member at the table, this is not a good arrangement. the table up or down will likely be determined by the crew after a while on orbit. i am not sure there is room for all of the food that would be required for a crew of 4 for 60 days. (or clothing or other hygiene items)
column61: the central location of the comm is good for work operations but not great for personal conversation.
column83: difficult to really evaluate given the level of fidelity.  but the hatch interferes with the exercise area, and there is no privacy, which could perhaps be made available with a curtain that could be deployed or not by crewmember preference. as is, the camera looks right at the exercise area which could be an issue for some
column91: there is not enough volume for cleaning up. simple solution might be to move the curtain further out from the wall.  not sure about configurability, not really tested. location is ok.
column98: too many pieces missing to really evaluate the activity
column105: i did not operate the hatch so those answers are meaningless. 1 minute for egree would be a challenge but probably doable
column131: perhaps configurable dividers, no permanent ones
column144: do not take away the windows unless you want a miserable crew. although i like the window in the exercise area, the one in the hygiene area should be moved forward. or placed in the galley area
column146: it is very difficult to evaluate right now
column148: i believe my previous comments address this
column149: well done overall.  I'd probably open the forward hatch up rather than to the side.

column14: Flight lesson, General aviation pilot, Simulated spaceflight, Working with human-spaceflight hardware, Zero-g aircraft
column15: NASA Shuttle Launch Control at KSC and Mission Operations Engineer at JSC
column41: Need better instructions/accommodations for personal hygiene eqpt, what do we do with washcloth after use?
column54: not clear where waste bag was, separate food stowage by category - breakfast, lunch, dinner and/or 1,2,3.   Add option for table to be configured if needed, not all or none
column61: need better headset stowage, shelf is crowded and mixed with emergency supplies
column83: The open airlock hatch was in the way of the treadmill area. There was no bike, which I was assigned to ride. Should take advantage of view out the window when setting this up for bike and treadmill.
column91: Hygiene volume was a little tight, but ok.  As for privacy, procedures had me changing clothes back in the main area!
column105: Alarm was not what was expected for master alarm, no instruction to remove the duct
column124: Generally straightforward, additional feedback given in real time and recommended suit stowage reconfiguration for more realistic layout.  Don't use the boots, cumbersome and no real value.
column144: In general, windows are nice, but in the mockup sim, they were not really all that visible.  Recommend putting the outward facing window on the PCM end and configuring it so it is more visible in the 1g mockup, and the Earth facing window would be nice to have so you could look out of it on the bike or treadmill
column146: Separate location of emergency O2 and headsets
column147: Storage, Command, Science, ECLSS, Technology Development

column14: Flight lesson, Flight crew member, General aviation pilot, Instrument rating, Simulated spaceflight, Long-duration spaceflight simulation, Living in close quarters, Working in remote or confined environments, Working with human-spaceflight hardware, Zero-g aircraft, Astronaut
column25: No procedure for hatch ops.  No labels with how to open hatch.  No indication of when hatch is unlatched.
column28: Activities at TCCS and CAMRAS interfered with duct installation
column54: The food storage area was accessible by only one crew member - it should be located away from the table area.  Same with the waste bag - it was behind a crew member at the table.
column61: A hand held microphone and speaker can work better than headsets unless privacy is desired.
column83: Need curtain moved to allow more room for hygiene
column105: No step in procedure for removing duct
column124: Need to change the question about EVA or IVA - I did both but could not provide that response.  Hatch was less than perfect because it does not open fully..
column131: No. Volume is not big enough to require dividers.
column144: Windows are important for psychological reasons.
column148: Food storage should be accessible without a crew member moving out of the way.

column14: Simulated spaceflight, Living in close quarters, Working in remote or confined environments, Working with human-spaceflight hardware, Zero-g aircraft
column15: Have flow on one 0G flight (~25 parabolas)
column25: A few items weren't labelled. It wasn't clear how many time I needed to rotate the  knob.
column28: Only getting in and out of the habitat to get items from PCM while configuring the ECLSS station was tricky.
column54: We couldn't find the waste bag or potable water. It was a little hard to get in an out of the food storage because only one crew member could get to that once everyone was at the table, and the door opened into them.
column61: Difficult to get the headsets out, but otherwise there was plenty of space to stand around for communication to the ground.
column91: Did not complete the exercise and hygiene tasks. So I just entered 3s for everything.
column98: Did not complete science tasks. So I just entered 3s.
column105: Was pretty easy to get out of the ICH.

column14: Worked in a facility not accessible by paved road
column15: Lived for a time a in a remote location not accessible by paved road
column28: Spacing was good. Crew member 3 was confused and doing tasks not assigned to them. Got in my way.
column61: Not very private. Would rather take personal calls or Skype in my sleep station
column83: Resistive machine was overlapping the treadmill
column146: A lot more storage space than needed
column148: I would work to remove any unnecessary storage

column25: Encountered difficulties/malfunctions. We're repairing issues with the HAB to PCM hatch
column41: Sleep station lights are blindingly bright especially considering that the walls are really white
column54: Food storage is really low to the ground and inconvenient to stoop Waste bag feels like it should be closer to table Need to reach across table to get to panel - inconvenient
column61: I would like to have some personal privacy for family communications rather than be in the middle of the hab
column75: Hatch is a little lower when considering lifting WPA 1 and having the steps in the way
column83: Never actually got to do the exercise scenario...
column91: That curtain is really really thin
column98: Tools were either left at the science station instead of storage or not in storage
column105: Confusing because we had to think to where the oxygen was. Also, were not aware we could stop the alarm. Took a few seconds to register an alarm was happening
column124: A little crowded in the airlock mostly because I was afriad of ripping the Mylar
column131: No, does not seem necessary given the sleep stations
column144: Windows are cool. They let me see space
column149: Ceiling of the hab area feels a little cramped compared to the open ceiling area
column164: Felt rather constrained by the suits and was afraid to rip mylar during EVA scenario

column15: Received Eagle Flight Certificate from Col. Voss
column41: Had enough volume to function, sleeping bag had fallen off. Overall functionality was good.
column54: Had to assign one crew member to do the re-hydration and heating tasks. Slight problem with reach of oven and water dispenser.
column61: I would prefer to have personal communication in the sleep station assigned, rather than the center of the hab
column83: Located in a reasonable space without the crew members in the way. Schedule conflict with CM1 for cardio.
column98: Could not complete the procedure. Was a bit hard to follow procedures.
column105: Was a confusing situation, we all died in the end. Hard to relate to a few things mentioned on the procedures.
column128: Was easier since I had walked through the procedure once. I think the airlock egress and ingress for CM 1 and 2 should be printed and pasted on the top of the airlock since they can easily follow procedures for repress and depress. We did not end up dying (in simulation) so it was a successful procedure.
column149: Yes please make sure that the hatch from ICH to PCM is in working conditions before testing.
column163: Inclusion of emergency exit to accommodate ingress if in any scenario, the hatches do not function.

column14: Simulated spaceflight, Worked with human-spaceflight hardware
column25: the hatch stop working during experiment
column28: my sleeping bag was hanging and i needed help
column41: my mirror was coverd by laptop - laptop fall during use and it did not hoocked back up
column75: It was confusing to get the stuff, i missed yellow tap and I had to look around
column83: your resistive device was on your treadmill
column128: 3 people in the airlock was tied
column148: was not clear where are the storage
column163: provide breaks - tell people to bring water-

column14: Received a flight lesson, Worked with human-spaceflight hardware, Worked in an environment in which four or more people shared sleeping space, Worked in a facility not accessible by paved road
column147: Airlock, Sleep Stations, Command, Science, Emergency Path
column170: HAB aft (to PCM), HAB forward (to airlock)

column14: Received a flight lesson, Non-pilot flight crew member, General aviation pilot, Worked with human-spaceflight hardware
column15: ~240 hours flight time including general aviation pilot in command, instrument rating training, military flight test engineer and aircrew member, and control room operations.
column25: Inner hatch to PCM required a bit of finesse to function properly. I'm not sure how well that would work in a contingency situation if the crew was under duress.
column28: It seemed like there was plenty of space for us to move around, even in 1 g.
column41: Seems like plenty of space to me. Much more space than I'm accustomed to with camping. Only gripe would be location of personal trash bag in sleeping quarters is close to sleeping bag.
column54: It may be a little cramped for 4 people in 1 g but seems like it would be perfectly fine for zero g. Only complaint is location of food storage may be a bit cumbersome to reach in zero g after you've gathered around the expanded table.
column61: Everything seemed to be completely acceptable.
column75: The air ducting through the hatch was poorly placed during the contingency.
column83: The treadmill was a bit too close to the front wall during exercise.
column98: Having the tools stored behind me during the science tasks was a bit cumbersome but not too badly.
column105: Having the air ducting in the escape path is very cumbersome. With training, the risk of the hatch design could be eliminated. I understand the mechanism of the hatch is simulated but the movement of the hatch was very clunky and slowed us down. I think it would be more realistic to have test crews train on emergency procedures before having them execute the procedures in a simulated contingency.
column131: I don't think spatial dividers would add anything to the habitat layout.
column144: For the test, the windows didn't add anything. But on a long duration mission I could see them as very important to overall crew happiness.
column148: Make the emergency path more free flowing (remove ducting from emergency path. Add more volume for the airlock.
column163: Improve the way you call out emergency procedures in the manual and make sure crew members are aware of where emergency life support items are located.
column164: The airlock seemed very small with two crewmembers inside it with EVA suits on. I still don't like the ducting being passed through the hatches.
column170: HAB aft (to PCM), HAB forward (to airlock)

column14: General aviation pilot, Worked with human-spaceflight hardware
column15: Private pilot training in progress, worked with ECLSS hardware, did an EVA simulation at US Space and Rocket Center at MSFC.
column28: Task instructions could be performed more smoothly if tasks were allocated to specific crew members.
column41: Overall, the sleep stations seemed spacious (if you imagine being in micro-g). The staggered layout seemed to be the best way to keep equal spacing between stations
column54: A little cramped. The velcro tabs could be larger
column61: For conference calls the command center is perfect, but would probably lack privacy for personal calls
column75: sleep station 2 was encroaching on exercise area
column91: Fairly cramped (expected), but I think the layout was good. window was a nice touch. Maybe a little too close to sleep station 2
column98: science stations are located in the largest open space.
column124: 2 crewmembers in EMUs would be super cramped
column131: Would reduce habitable volume, but would add more space to attach items to walls
column144: The windows would be great for psychological health. Especially the one facing Earth. It wasn't even real and it felt strange to see it that way (in a good way)
column146: Honestly I think if volume in any area could be spared, it would be storage. Could utilize more velcro for tools, etc.
column149: I think you could bunch all the sleeping quarters together and not have a problem
column163: More intuitive lingo, but also it was only our first run, so with practice we could get more familiar. Overall the procedures were thorough.

column25: Going in took a bit of fiddling, but overall it wasn't that much of a nuisance.
column41: The sleeping quarters were so functional that I would neither mind nor in all likelihood notice if they were closer together or farther apart.
column54: It would be nice if, in addition to the main table, there were several smaller collapsible tables for miscellaneous use.
column75: The width was especially clunky with respect to most of the equipment carried through it and was occasionally a problem.
column105: Both emergency procedure and emergency equipment location could have been further optimized.
column124: I was cramped a little, but with training I feel like this wouldn't be an issue.
column131: Perhaps pullout dividers if there was room for them to slide out.
column144: I feel these windows were underutilized in the simulation, but long term I feel that windows would be very important.
column148: I feel that the sleep stations could have been a bit smaller and still functional, and I feel that science needed a dedicated table for ideal effect.
column163: Perhaps email the procedures ahead of time.
column164: The hygiene area was quite close to the unstable edge of the hull.
column170: PCM forward (to HAB), HAB aft (to PCM)
